The Castle Doctrine does nothing to entitle people to shoot any unexpected person walking to their door. That is completely misleading. The law has been misrepresented since it's inception.
Shooting someone as you describe is murder (or attempted murder) and we just saw a conviction for this in Detroit (and rightfully so). The gun lobby has done nothing to protect Mr. Wafer.

This matter has become a recent issue with postal workers who are sometimes now being directed to work in the dark.  With state after state passing Castle Doctrine laws, more and more people feel entitled to shoot any unexpected person who walks to their door at night. Postal workers are rightly saying no - not at a time when state legislatures are giving "shoot first, ask questions later" their blessing.

Although I generally agree with you about the purpose of education, I think that many, if not most, people see a very different purpose. Many think that it is the place where one learns the norms of society and learns to conform and do what's expected. A related view is that the purpose is to get specific training in order to fit into the work force, or advance one's career prospects.  Good luck with making the case that it should be about stretching one's boundaries.

While greed is not against the law in the USA or Russia the core difference is a free press. The list of allegations you make, while I agree in principle, would not likely be published in Pravda or other 'leading' newspaper of record in the new Russia.  History does rhyme and the current affairs of Russian big business and cronyism seems to follow a pattern that the anti-trust laws in the USA attempted to curtail. The greatest threat to the US is the unwillingness of its governors to close the loopholes in taxation, corporate and securities laws and enforce a strict zero tolerance policy. I don't think putting people in jail for multiple lifetimes is a smart solution as jails for rich and powerful are often detention halls with bar services. Would it not be better simply to penalize felons by recovering all the wealth that was ill-begotten from greedy unlawful activities? Another benefit of good laws is that the law firms that provide bespoke services to the select few multi-millionaires who get caught with their fingers in the cookie jar may turn their inquisitive minds to less profitable business like class actions on behalf of ordinary citizens who are not able to advance worthy claims against deep pocket corporate litigants for lack of financing that funds organization that is required to engage lawyers to advance 'justice for all' instead of the few rich who have the best of all world's under current laws that serve and protect wealth over all other interests.
And it sure pays to live in a country where you can write such things without being jailed like Pussy Riot.

Yes, there is crony capitalism in both countries.  If you work for a multinational see if there is a comparable position in Russia.  You could also go to Russia to start a business.  I guaranty you will know the difference in a very short time.

Your test-prep teachers were probably capable of actually teaching.  They were just in fear of losing their jobs if they did, something the teacher you praise was risking, for actually teaching in the current "education reform" climate.

As a current college student, I can openly say that my public high school education felt like I was put in a bubble, created by a bigger bubble, that was filled with teachers trained to teach the bare minimum in order to raise the test scores. And, of course, in raising the test scores, those in the bigger bubble might have gotten a little raise themselves. The class where I learned the most was the class where the teacher shed light on the harsh reality of this bubble-- this education system that caters to test scores and not offending students, rather than expanding their minds and helping students grow as intellectuals. If we want our students to grow, we need to start teaching outside of the coddled bubbles.

A Russian friend of mine said the other day: "The West is lucky that President Putin has shown such restraint." I agreed. I recall Mr. Obama's taunting Russia with: "they don't even make anything anymore". I'm not sure who makes them, but I know Russia has more than a few nuclear weapons in its arsenal.

Today I saw Obama waxing eloquent on why endless war is now necessary if the world is to survive. Mr. Obama looked unwell-- not only gray, but skeletal. I've felt for a long time that he is in waters way over his head.

PBS aired a recent documentary on the cuban missle crisis a few weeks ago. It showed clearly how the judgement, courage and character of John and Robert Kennedy...and Nikita Kruschev probably saved the world from nuclear war.

Today I see my government pushing us dangerously towards a potential nuclear confrontation with Russia. I have no confidence whatsoever, that there are cool and wise and courageous leaders in Washington or the White House who could or would prevent us from going over the abyss.

This often keeps me awake at nite.

Tom Rutter

The problem with the studies regarding the safety of persons who have guns in the home is that they have no context. If it is the case that criminals are more likely to be murdered than people not engaged in crime, then it would follow that somebody operating in a criminal enterprise would keep a gun with them at all times which would skew the statistics. In other words, a gangbanger probably has a gun and is infinitely more likely to be targeted to be killed in his home. Since gangbangers are killed and shot at a higher rate than the normal person, it skews the stats and doesn't answer the question of whether a normal everyday person is safer or not with a gun in the home.

Although I strongly disagree with the approach that Mr. Kristof took re: the recovery of his stolen phone, I completely agree with his larger point about the fear mongering that certain groups use to encourage citizens to own guns for their personal safety.  In study after study, we see that death and injury rates increase dramatically when there is a gun in the home. That said, we're not dealing with rational actors here. A friend from college (top 10 school) posted on Facebook today that she thought Sandy Hook was a hoax cooked up by the government in order to impose stronger gun controls.  As a country, I'm afraid we're beyond all hope if even our "best and brightest" are this delusional.

The Soviet Union's collapse and subsequent rise of a Russian Fascist dictator ruling a one party state mirrors what happened in Germany during the "Interwar" period.

After the General Staff forced the Kaiser to abdicate to save itself the successor government, supposedly a break from authoritarianism but actually a junta styled the "Weimar Republic", confronted an economic maelstrom of hyperinflation, recession and, finally, a depression that destroyed its legitimacy. Hitler, a revolutionary leading of a revanchist political party centered around himself, aimed to overthrow it, but through legal means. That meant President-Field Marshal von Hindenburg had to appoint him Chancellor, which meant Hitler's party had to win the Reichstag election. So Hitler promised Germany's leading capitalists he would create vast fiefdoms for them protected by a "new order" if they financed his party.

What this "new order" would be and how it would operate was clearly spelled out in his book "My Struggle". After Hitler conquered the Soviet Union as planned and forced a peace treaty on a beseiged UK and defeated France (1918, in reverse) not only would Germany have won The Great War (as Marshal Foch predicted in 1918, opposing the Armistice) his "Great Germany" would been the most powerful nation on Earth and he, its richest man; a 20th century Charlemagne. His personal fiefdom, created by Martin Bormann among others, would have comprised much of Ukraine.

Ecce Caesar Augustus. And Putin.
